title: How to Make Herbal Indian Shampoo

steps.title: Soak soap nuts, dried gooseberry, and dried shikakai for 12 hours.
steps.content: Soak soap nuts, dried gooseberry, and dried shikakai for 12 hours. Fill a large pot with water and then pour 25 g (1/3 cup) of soap nuts, 25 g (1/3 cup) of dried gooseberry, and 25 g (1/3 cup) of dried shikakai into the water. Let the ingredients soak overnight, or for about 12 hours, so they get soft. [1] X Research source Soap nuts provide a small lather to your shampoo so it’s easier to wash your hair with. Gooseberry helps to promote blood flow to the scalp and new hair growth. shikakai has antibacterial and antifungal properties to help prevent dandruff. Your ingredients will be much easier to use after they’ve soaked since they won’t be hard and dry anymore. You can also substitute the shikakai for 2 tbsp (28 g) of Fenugreek seeds. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Boil your mixture over medium heat.
steps.content: Boil your mixture over medium heat. Keeping your ingredients in the same pot, put them on the stove and turn it to medium heat. Wait until you see large bubbles rise to the top of the water to tell that it’s boiling. [3] X Research source The water may turn muddy and brown as you boil it.

steps.title: Scoop out the soap nuts and remove the seeds.
steps.content: Scoop out the soap nuts and remove the seeds. Use a spoon to scoop out the soap nuts from the pot. With your fingers, gently peel open the outside of the soap nuts to reveal the soft center. Throw away the outside shell and put the inside of the nut back into your mixture. [4] X Research source Opening up the soap nuts will help them blend better into your shampoo.

steps.title: Boil a pot of aloe vera, hibiscus leaves, and tulsi leaves.
steps.content: Boil a pot of aloe vera, hibiscus leaves, and tulsi leaves. Add 3 cups (710 mL) of water to a different pot, then put in 1/2 cup (64 g) of aloe vera, 1/2 cup (64 g) of hibiscus leaves, and 1/2 cup (64 g) of tulsi leaves. Turn the stovetop onto medium heat and wait until you see large bubbles rising to the top of the water. [5] X Research source You don’t have to be exact with your measurements here, since the herbal mixture will benefit your hair no matter what ratio it’s at. Hibiscus helps to promote hair growth, tulsi leaves help to reduce itching and dandruff, and aloe vera has a lot of moisture to keep your hair smooth and shiny.

steps.title: Combine both pots, then blend the mixture.
steps.content: Combine both pots, then blend the mixture. Carefully pour both of your pots of liquid into a blender, then pulse the blender 4 to 5 times. Try to blend your shampoo into a pulp, but not a smooth juice. [6] X Research source You can also use a handheld blender and blend your ingredients in the pot on the stove, if you have one.

steps.title: Strain the liquid into a glass jar.
steps.content: Strain the liquid into a glass jar. Hold a fine mesh strainer over a glass jar and pour your blended mixture through it. Once liquid stops running out from the pulp in the strainer, you can throw the pulp away. [7] X Research source Make sure your jar can hold at least 12 fluid ounces (0.35 L). Don’t push the pulp through the strainer, or you could end up with a chunky shampoo.

steps.title: Store your shampoo in the jar with a lid on it.
steps.content: Store your shampoo in the jar with a lid on it. Make sure the lid on your bottle is airtight to keep the ingredients fresh and smelling good. You can keep your shampoo in your shower to use it every time you wash your hair for a natural alternative to shampoo! [8] X Research source Try to use your herbal shampoo within 3 months for the best results.

steps.title: Shake the bottle every time you use your shampoo.
steps.content: Shake the bottle every time you use your shampoo. Some separation of your ingredients is natural. Make sure the lid is on tight and shake your bottle for about 10 seconds before you use it in your hair. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Pour a quarter-sized amount of shampoo into your palm.
steps.content: Pour a quarter-sized amount of shampoo into your palm. You don’t need a ton of herbal shampoo to get your hair clean. Try starting out with less than you think you need, then adding more. Pour some shampoo into your palms and rub it around briefly to get a slight lather. [10] X Research source Herbal shampoos won’t lather up as much as synthetic shampoos do since they don’t have lathering chemicals in them.

steps.title: Rub the shampoo into your hair, then rinse it out.
steps.content: Rub the shampoo into your hair, then rinse it out. Focus on your scalp as you apply the shampoo all over your head. Once you’ve covered your scalp completely, rinse the shampoo out with lukewarm water until you can’t feel it on your hair anymore. [11] X Research source The shampoo from your scalp will run down to the ends of your hair as you rinse so that all of your hair gets clean.

steps.title: Rinse your hair with apple cider vinegar.
steps.content: Rinse your hair with apple cider vinegar. When you first start using herbal shampoos, your hair may feel oily or weighed down after you wash it. If you need to, wash your hair a second time with apple cider vinegar to remove all of the oil from your hair and leave it feeling clean. Rinse your hair with lukewarm water to get all of the vinegar out. [12] X Research source
